post_text: We appreciate the patience and support from our families as we returned to school. Our teachers, staff, and admin have worked diligently to adapt in order to continue providing a great education for your children. Our schools will continue in-person classes at all schools, with the option for virtual classes for families that chose to remain virtual after the Aug. 21 deadline. JCS work with the health department regularly to monitor health-related issues. Thank you again for your support.

post_text: These are the current guidelines for students to return to school after a positive COVID-19 test result or was a close contact to a confirmed positive case. You will be contacted directly by school personnel if it has been determined that your child is a possible close contact of a confirmed positive case. Always follow your healthcare provider's recommendation.

post_text:
Jackson County Needs a Higher Response Rate- only 55% have responded so far.

The 2020 Census is important. Results to the 2020 Census determine how many seats our state gets in Congress and how public funds are received and spent on schools, roads, fire and emergency services, hospitals, and much more in our community. The rates of funding to support special education, teacher training, and at-risk student programs are determined from the census. Our response rate is too low! Please respond if you haven’t already.

Respond Online:
https://2020census.gov

Respond by Phone:
844-330-2020 (English)
844-468-2020 (Spanish)

post_text:
The Jackson County Board of Education passed an amended version of the 2020-2021 School Reopening Plan. The school year will begin in person and on time, with a virtual option.

Changes include requiring employees to wear a face mask, face covering, or face shields when in an area where social distancing is not feasible.

Face coverings or face shields will be recommended for students.

The most up to date health department guidelines for schools will continue to be followed.

Virtual (online) students will be permitted to participate in extracurricular activities.

The deadline to apply for virtual instruction will be extended through tomorrow.

The updated plan will be posted on this page and our school websites as soon as the updated version is ready to publish.
text:

Face coverings or face shields will be recommended for students.

The most up to date health department guidelines for schools will continue to be followed.

Virtual (online) students will be permitted to participate in extracurricular activities.

The deadline to apply for virtual instruction will be extended through tomorrow.

The updated plan will be posted on this page and our school websites as soon as the updated version is ready to publish.

A more detailed plan and student handbooks for virtual instruction will be published upon finalization and approval. We want to open schools safely, while also respecting each family’s choice for their circumstances.

post_text: We look forward to educating and suppporting your child when schools open in August! Tremendous efforts are being made for your child's safe return to our schools. Thank you for your feedback on our previous survey. A new update will be communicated on or before July 15th. Here's our current update:
text: We look forward to educating and suppporting your child when schools open in August! Tremendous efforts are being made for your child's safe return to our schools. Thank you for your feedback on our previous survey. A new update will be communicated on or before July 15th. Here's our current update:

post_text:
We hope your child returns to our school buildings for traditional classes when instruction begins in August. However, we respect families' decisions to choose a virtual instruction program due to the COVID-19 pandemic and health concerns for your child. If you are certain you wish for your child to begin the year with virtual instruction, please read the requirements and fill out the application FOR EACH CHILD by July23: https://forms.gle/7E1hTPjVGU6ZSvDbA
ONLY COMPLETE THE APPLICATION IF YOUR CHILD WILL BEGIN THE SCHOOL YEAR WITH THE VIRTUAL INSTRUCTION PROGRAM.

post_text: Jackson County Schools purchased two brand new buses recently. The one pictured here was funded through the VW Settlement Environmental Mitigation Grant program. Transportation Supervisor Phyllis Goad worked with the TN Department if Environment and Conservation on the grant and the purchasing of both buses after the school board’s approval. A second bus is scheduled to arrive soon.
text: Jackson County Schools purchased two brand new buses recently. The one pictured here was funded through the VW Settlement Environmental Mitigation Grant program. Transportation Supervisor Phyllis Goad worked with the TN Department if Environment and Conservation on the grant and the purchasing of both buses after the school board’s approval. A second bus is scheduled to arrive soon.

post_text:
June 26, 2020–
The survey will remain open, but we are planning for all students to return to school in person with health guidelines in place to the greatest extent possible. We plan to provide chrome books K-12 in case of school closures due to illness, provide transportation on buses, and we have stocked up on cleaning supplies and sanitizer. We are getting our buildings ready! After reading comments, your top concerns are masks, social distancing measures, transportation, sharing materials, and options for virtual learning for students with health concerns or illness. Jackson County Schools will communicate more detailed plans by July 3. We will continue to monitor the situation and consult with health officials. Of course, recommendations could change. Thank you so much for your thoughtful, sincere comments, concerns, and suggestions. All of them are being considered. Here are the results so far.
text:
June 26, 2020–
The survey will remain open, but we are planning for all students to return to school in person with health guidelines in place to the greatest extent possible. We plan to provide chrome books K-12 in case of school closures due to illness, provide transportation on buses, and we have stocked up on cleaning supplies and sanitizer. We are getting our buildings ready! After reading comments, your top concerns are masks, social distancing measures, transportation, sharing materials, and options for virtual learning for students with health concerns or illness. Jackson County Schools will communicate more detailed plans by July 3. We will continue to monitor the situation and consult with health officials. Of course, recommendations could change. Thank you so much for your thoughtful, sincere comments, concerns, and suggestions. All of them are being considered. Here are the results so far.

post_text:
Our intent is that all students will return to school as normally as possible in August with safety precautions in place to prevent the spread of COVID-19. However, we understand that some students may have circumstances that need to be considered.

Planning for safety, instruction, transportation, technology, nutrition, and student services are in the works to prepare to support our students no matter what challenges we face for next school year. On the survey that was sent out today, be sure to comment on any concerns you have regarding students returning to school.
text:
Our intent is that all students will return to school as normally as possible in August with safety precautions in place to prevent the spread of COVID-19. However, we understand that some students may have circumstances that need to be considered.

Planning for safety, instruction, transportation, technology, nutrition, and student services are in the works to prepare to support our students no matter what challenges we face for next school year. On the survey that was sent out today, be sure to comment on any concerns you have regarding students returning to school.

Updated information will be communicated by July 1, 2020.

post_text:
ALL SCHOOL FAMILIES ELIGIBLE FOR $256.50 PER SCHOOL-AGED CHILD!
Because the Jackson County School Nutrition Program participates in the free breakfast and lunch program in JACKSON COUNTY SCHOOLS, families are eligible for $256.50 per school-aged child! Click here to apply for the P-EBT funds:

https://tdhs.service-now.com/relief?id=relief_registration
shared_text:
Jackson County Nutrition Program
June 15 at 7:20 PM ·

The TN Department of Human Services and the Tennessee Department of Education announced Tennessee families are now eligible to receive financial support for their children’s nutritional needs during the COVID-19 pandemic. This support is provided through the Pandemic Electronic Benefit Transfer (P-EBT) Program.

The P-EBT application site is NOW OPEN!

ALL JACKSON COUNTY SCHOOL STUDENTS ARE ELIGIBLE!

Please refer to the flyer below for information. The link to the official press release and application process can be found at https://www.tn.gov/humanservices/news/2020/6/15/financial-assistance-available-for-families-that-qualify-for-free-and-reduced-school-lunches-.html

The application process is not through the school system, so you must log on and complete that step yourself. If you have questions or issues please call 1-833-496-0661.

We encourage all of our families to take advantage of this opportunity.

Information will be shared for each school on social media, automated calls, and your child’s google classroom or other online class page.

post_text:
Hello School Families,
I hope you and your families are well. School Meal pick-ups are still going on, but we are limiting access to school buidlings in response to the Governor's Executive Order No. 22 and 23. The TN Department of Education is asking for input on what to prioritize when applying for federal funding related to school closures. Fill out the survey to let them know what you think. Email me anytime at kristybrown@jacksoncoschools.com to share your input with me. Thank you all for your patience, understanding, and support of our schools during this challenging time. We miss our students!
https://stateoftennessee.formstack.com/forms/public_cares_survey?mc_cid=8a1d0b7602&mc_eid=56b4261abd

post_text: Be a Santa to a Student is a huge success! Everyone had so much fun making sure the Christmas wishes of children in Jackson County are fulfilled. Torri Carver started and leads this program for our students and their families. So many kids are going to be very happy again this year. Special thank you to Torri, her mom Denise, our bus drivers, central office staff, gift wrappers, and every person that sponsored a child for this wonderful program.
text: Be a Santa to a Student is a huge success! Everyone had so much fun making sure the Christmas wishes of children in Jackson County are fulfilled. Torri Carver started and leads this program for our students and their families. So many kids are going to be very happy again this year. Special thank you to Torri, her mom Denise, our bus drivers, central office staff, gift wrappers, and every person that sponsored a child for this wonderful program.

post_text:
Jackson County Schools Awarded Safe Schools Grant for School Resource Officers:
Jackson County Schools have been awarded $70,000 through the Tennessee Department of Education to put toward funding two additional full-time School Resource Officers. The funding is part of Governor Bill Lee’s $40 million investment for school safety grants, which prioritizes School Resource Officers being placed in underserved areas and in schools that currently do not have full-time SROs. The grant funds will allow every school in Jackson County to have a designated officer onsite. This funding was secured in collaboration with the Jackson County Board of Education, Coordinated School Health Coordinator Jennifer Scott, Jackson County Mayor Randy Heady, Sheriff Marty Hinson, and the Jackson County Commission. Student safety is a top priority for our schools and this is a major step forward in further securing our students and staff.

post_text: This information was released from the Sheriffs Dept. Jackson County Schools will continue to do everything we can to protect students, faculty, and staff. The coordinated efforts between the school and law enforcement agencies are to be commended. We appreciate the patience and cooperation from parents and the community as well. Additional staff will be available as a resource for students.

post_text: We want to inform parents that we received a report of a possible weapon at Jackson County Middle School. Upon immediate investigation, a weapon was confiscated. School administration is working with the local sheriffs department. All students are safe and accounted for in our schools. Any information we are able to share will be released when it’s confirmed.

shared_text:
The Blue Devil Life
April 10, 2019 at 4:45 PM ·

The Tennessee Valley Authority, in partnership with Bicentennial Volunteers Incorporated (a TVA retiree organization), recently awarded Jackson County High School, $2500 for a STEM (science, technology, engineering, and math) education project.

Kent Shepherd, Biology Teacher at JCHS shared, “We are so excited to have the opportunity to use this grant to expose more students to our beautiful resources here in Jackson County.”

The project Jackson County High School submitted will provide wet suits and water quality kits to extend the time we can spend researching The Boils Wildlife Management Area and our state park Cummins Falls. Twice this year students spent time snorkeling at these areas with professionals from TWRA, TDEC and our State Parks. This grant will provide this opportunity for more students next year.
text:

April 10, 2019 at 4:45 PM ·

The Tennessee Valley Authority, in partnership with Bicentennial Volunteers Incorporated (a TVA retiree organization), recently awarded Jackson County High School, $2500 for a STEM (science, technology, engineering, and math) education project.

Kent Shepherd, Biology Teacher at JCHS shared, “We are so excited to have the opportunity to use this grant to expose more students to our beautiful resources here in Jackson County.”

The project Jackson County High School submitted will provide wet suits and water quality kits to extend the time we can spend researching The Boils Wildlife Management Area and our state park Cummins Falls. Twice this year students spent time snorkeling at these areas with professionals from TWRA, TDEC and our State Parks. This grant will provide this opportunity for more students next year.

post_text: 2 HOUR DELAY: We have been consulted by law enforcement, highway department, rescue personnel, checked many roads, and received information from TEMA this morning regarding water levels. Jackson County Schools are still 2 hours late today February 25.
text: 2 HOUR DELAY: We have been consulted by law enforcement, highway department, rescue personnel, checked many roads, and received information from TEMA this morning regarding water levels. Jackson County Schools are still 2 hours late today February 25.

post_text: As a precaution, Jackson County Schools will open 2 hours late on MONDAY, FEBRUARY 25 with bus driver discretion.
text: As a precaution, Jackson County Schools will open 2 hours late on MONDAY, FEBRUARY 25 with bus driver discretion.

post_text: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 24: The road conditions and updates on potential flooding will be monitored throughout tonight and in the morning. The decision on schools being opened, delayed, or closed will be made as soon as possible with the safety of our students and employees as the top priority. Thank you for your support and patience.
